Python: Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for readability and versatility.
JavaScript: JavaScript is a versatile programming language primarily used for web development.
HTML: HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language, used to structure content on the web.
CSS: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets, used to style and design web pages.
API: An API (Application Programming Interface) allows communication between software applications.
AI: AI simulates human intelligence in machines that can perform tasks like reasoning, learning, and problem-solving.
Machine Learning: Machine learning is a subset of AI where algorithms improve automatically through experience.
Neural Network: A neural network is a set of algorithms designed to recognize patterns in data.
Deep Learning: Deep learning is a type of machine learning using multi-layered neural networks.
Algorithm: An algorithm is a set of instructions for solving a problem or performing a task.
Function: A function is a reusable block of code that performs a specific task.
Variable: A variable is a storage location paired with an associated symbolic name, containing data.
Loop: A loop is a programming construct that repeats a block of code multiple times.
Conditional: A conditional statement executes a block of code if a specified condition is true.
Object: An object is a collection of data and methods that act on that data in object-oriented programming.
Class: A class is a blueprint for creating objects in object-oriented programming.
Inheritance: Inheritance allows one class to adopt properties and methods from another class.
Encapsulation: Encapsulation restricts access to certain details of an object, exposing only necessary parts.
Polymorphism: Polymorphism allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common superclass.
Data Structure: A data structure is a particular way of organizing and storing data for efficient access and modification.
Array: An array is a collection of elements, each identified by an index or key.
List: A list is an ordered collection of items which can be modified dynamically.
Dictionary: A dictionary is a collection of key-value pairs, used for fast lookup.
Set: A set is an unordered collection of unique elements.
Tuple: A tuple is an immutable, ordered collection of elements.
Stack: A stack is a collection of elements that follows the Last-In-First-Out principle.
Queue: A queue is a collection of elements that follows the First-In-First-Out principle.
Graph: A graph is a set of nodes connected by edges, used to represent relationships.
Tree: A tree is a hierarchical data structure with nodes connected by edges.
Binary Tree: A binary tree is a tree data structure in which each node has at most two children.
Sorting Algorithm: A sorting algorithm arranges the elements of a list in a certain order.
Search Algorithm: A search algorithm finds the location of a specific element in a data structure.
Recursion: Recursion is when a function calls itself to solve a smaller instance of a problem.
Exception: An exception is an error that occurs during program execution, which can be handled.
Debugging: Debugging is the process of finding and fixing errors in code.
Framework: A framework is a platform for developing software applications with prebuilt components.
Library: A library is a collection of reusable functions and modules for programming.
Database: A database is a structured collection of data stored electronically.
SQL: SQL (Structured Query Language) is used to communicate with and manipulate databases.
NoSQL: NoSQL databases store data in a non-tabular form, suitable for unstructured or semi-structured data.
Server: A server is a computer or system that provides resources or services to other computers over a network.
Client: A client is a computer or software that accesses services provided by a server.
Cloud Computing: Cloud computing delivers computing resources over the internet on-demand.
Virtual Machine: A virtual machine is an emulation of a computer system within another computer.
Container: A container is a lightweight, standalone executable package of software that includes everything needed to run it.
Docker: Docker is a platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers.
Kubernetes: Kubernetes is a system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.
Big Data: Big data refers to extremely large data sets that can be analyzed computationally to reveal patterns and insights.
Data Mining: Data mining is the process of discovering patterns in large data sets using machine learning, statistics, and database systems.
Statistics: Statistics is the study of collecting, analyzing, interpreting, and presenting data.
Probability: Probability measures the likelihood that an event will occur.
Linear Regression: Linear regression is a method to model the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables.
Logistic Regression: Logistic regression models the probability of a binary outcome.
Classification: Classification is a type of supervised learning where the goal is to predict discrete labels.
Clustering: Clustering is an unsupervised learning technique that groups similar data points together.
Decision Tree: A decision tree is a model that predicts the value of a target variable by learning simple decision rules from data.
Random Forest: Random forest is an ensemble learning method that constructs multiple decision trees for prediction.
Support Vector Machine: SVM is a supervised learning algorithm for classification and regression tasks.
Neural Network Layer: A neural network layer consists of multiple neurons that process input and pass output to the next layer.
Activation Function: An activation function defines the output of a neuron given an input or set of inputs.
Gradient Descent: Gradient descent is an optimization algorithm used to minimize a loss function by iteratively adjusting parameters.
Backpropagation: Backpropagation is a method used to train neural networks by propagating errors backward through the network.
Overfitting: Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data too well and fails to generalize to new data.
Underfitting: Underfitting occurs when a model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern in data.
Epoch: An epoch is a complete pass through the entire training dataset during model training.
Batch Size: Batch size is the number of training examples used in one iteration of model training.
Learning Rate: Learning rate determines the size of steps the optimizer takes to reach the minimum of the loss function.
Regularization: Regularization is a technique to prevent overfitting by penalizing large weights in a model.
Dropout: Dropout is a regularization method that randomly disables neurons during training to prevent overfitting.
Convolution: Convolution is a mathematical operation used in convolutional neural networks to process image data.
Pooling: Pooling is a downsampling operation in neural networks that reduces the spatial dimensions of input.
Recurrent Neural Network: RNN is a neural network architecture suitable for sequential data like text and time series.
Long Short-Term Memory: LSTM is a type of RNN that can learn long-term dependencies in sequence data.
Generative Adversarial Network: GANs are neural networks where two models (generator and discriminator) compete to improve generation of data.
Computer Vision: Computer vision enables machines to interpret and process visual information from the world.
Natural Language Processing: NLP is a field of AI focused on interaction between computers and human language.
Tokenization: Tokenization is the process of splitting text into smaller units such as words or subwords.
Stemming: Stemming reduces words to their base or root form.
Lemmatization: Lemmatization reduces words to their dictionary form.
Word Embedding: Word embeddings are vector representations of words capturing semantic meaning.
Sentiment Analysis: Sentiment analysis is the process of determining the emotional tone of text.
Chatbot: A chatbot is an AI system that can interact with users through text or voice conversation.
Turing Test: The Turing test evaluates whether a machine can exhibit intelligent behavior indistinguishable from a human.
Algorithm Complexity: Algorithm complexity describes the performance and resource usage of an algorithm.
Big O Notation: Big O notation expresses the upper bound of an algorithm's runtime or space requirement.

Blockchain: A blockchain is a decentralized digital ledger that records transactions across multiple computers.
Bitcoin: Bitcoin is a decentralized digital currency based on blockchain technology.
Ethereum: Ethereum is a blockchain platform that allows creation of smart contracts and decentralized apps.
Smart Contract: A smart contract is a self-executing contract with the terms directly written into code.
Cryptography: Cryptography is the practice of secure communication in the presence of adversaries.
Encryption: Encryption converts readable data into unreadable form to protect it from unauthorized access.
Decryption: Decryption converts encrypted data back into its readable form using a key.
Hash Function: A hash function converts input data into a fixed-length string of characters, used in security and data integrity.
Public Key: A public key is used in asymmetric cryptography to encrypt data or verify digital signatures.
Private Key: A private key is used in asymmetric cryptography to decrypt data or create digital signatures.
Token: A token is a digital asset issued on a blockchain representing a unit of value.
NFT: NFT stands for Non-Fungible Token, a unique digital asset representing ownership of digital items.
Wallet: A wallet stores digital currencies and keys used to access them.
Mining: Mining is the process of validating transactions and adding them to the blockchain ledger.
Proof of Work: Proof of Work is a consensus algorithm that requires computational effort to validate transactions.
Proof of Stake: Proof of Stake is a consensus algorithm where validators are chosen based on the amount of stake they hold.
Distributed Ledger: A distributed ledger is a database that is replicated, shared, and synchronized across multiple sites.
AI Ethics: AI ethics studies moral issues and societal impact of AI deployment.
Bias in AI: Bias in AI occurs when a model reflects prejudices present in the training data.
Explainable AI: Explainable AI (XAI) aims to make AI decision-making understandable to humans.
Autonomous Vehicle: An autonomous vehicle is capable of sensing the environment and navigating without human input.
Computer Graphics: Computer graphics is the creation, manipulation, and representation of visual images using computers.
3D Modeling: 3D modeling is the process of creating a three-dimensional representation of an object.
Rendering: Rendering is generating an image from a model using computer software.
Animation: Animation is the process of creating the illusion of motion by displaying a sequence of images.
Virtual Reality: Virtual Reality (VR) immerses users in a simulated 3D environment.
Augmented Reality: Augmented Reality (AR) overlays digital content onto the real-world environment.
Mixed Reality: Mixed Reality (MR) combines real and virtual worlds to produce new environments and interactions.
IoT: The Internet of Things (IoT) is a network of physical devices connected to the internet.
Smart Home: A smart home uses IoT devices to automate and control household functions.
Wearable Tech: Wearable technology includes devices worn on the body that monitor or enhance human capabilities.
Quantum Computing: Quantum computing uses quantum bits to perform computations much faster than classical computers.
Qubit: A qubit is the fundamental unit of quantum information.
Superposition: Superposition allows a qubit to exist in multiple states simultaneously.
Entanglement: Entanglement is a quantum phenomenon where particles remain connected, affecting each other instantly at a distance.
Photon: A photon is a particle representing a quantum of light.
Electron: An electron is a subatomic particle with a negative charge.
Proton: A proton is a positively charged particle found in the nucleus of an atom.
Neutron: A neutron is a neutral particle found in the nucleus of an atom.
Atom: An atom is the smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element.
Molecule: A molecule is a group of atoms bonded together.
Chemical Reaction: A chemical reaction involves the rearrangement of atoms to form new substances.
Catalyst: A catalyst speeds up a chemical reaction without being consumed.
Photosynthesis: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert sunlight into chemical energy.
Respiration: Respiration is the process by which living organisms convert nutrients into energy.
DNA: DNA carries genetic instructions for growth, development, and reproduction of organisms.
RNA: RNA translates genetic instructions from DNA into proteins.
Protein: Proteins are large molecules that perform various functions in living organisms.
Enzyme: An enzyme is a protein that speeds up chemical reactions in living organisms.
Cell: A cell is the basic structural, functional, and biological unit of life.
Neuron: A neuron is a nerve cell that transmits information via electrical and chemical signals.
Synapse: A synapse is the junction between two neurons where communication occurs.
Brain: The brain is the organ that controls thought, memory, emotion, touch, motor skills, vision, and more.
Heart: The heart pumps blood through the circulatory system.
Lungs: The lungs facilitate the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the respiratory system.
Immune System: The immune system defends the body against pathogens.
Vaccine: A vaccine stimulates the immune system to recognize and fight specific pathogens.
Antibody: An antibody is a protein that neutralizes foreign substances like bacteria and viruses.
Antigen: An antigen is a molecule capable of triggering an immune response.
Computer: A computer is an electronic device that processes data according to instructions.
CPU: The CPU (Central Processing Unit) executes instructions of a computer program.
GPU: A GPU (Graphics Processing Unit) is specialized for rendering graphics and parallel processing.
RAM: RAM (Random Access Memory) is fast, temporary memory used by the computer.
ROM: ROM (Read-Only Memory) stores data that cannot be modified easily.
Hard Drive: A hard drive is a data storage device that uses magnetic storage to store and retrieve digital information.
SSD: A solid-state drive (SSD) is a storage device that uses integrated circuits to store data.
Networking: Networking is connecting computers and devices to share resources and information.
IP Address: An IP address is a unique identifier assigned to each device connected to a network.
DNS: DNS (Domain Name System) translates domain names into IP addresses.
HTTP: HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) is used for transferring web pages on the internet.
HTTPS: HTTPS is the secure version of HTTP, using encryption for data transfer.
Firewall: A firewall monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on security rules.
Malware: Malware is malicious software designed to damage, disrupt, or gain unauthorized access to systems.
Virus: A computer virus is a type of malware that replicates and spreads to other programs or systems.
Trojan: A Trojan is malware disguised as legitimate software to trick users into installing it.
Phishing: Phishing is a cyberattack that attempts to trick people into revealing sensitive information.
VPN: A VPN (Virtual Private Network) creates a secure connection over the internet.
Cloud Storage: Cloud storage allows storing data on remote servers accessed via the internet.
Serverless Computing: Serverless computing allows developers to run code without managing servers.
Edge Computing: Edge computing processes data closer to the source, reducing latency.

Machine Learning: Machine Learning is a branch of AI where systems learn from data to make predictions or decisions.
Supervised Learning: Supervised learning trains a model on labeled data to predict outcomes for new data.
Unsupervised Learning: Unsupervised learning finds patterns in unlabeled data without predefined outputs.
Reinforcement Learning: Reinforcement learning teaches agents to make decisions by rewarding desired behaviors.
Neural Network: A neural network is a model inspired by the human brain that processes data in layers of interconnected nodes.
Deep Learning: Deep learning uses multi-layered neural networks to model complex patterns in data.
Convolutional Neural Network: CNNs are specialized for processing grid-like data, like images.
Recurrent Neural Network: RNNs are designed for sequential data, such as text or time series.
Natural Language Processing: NLP enables machines to understand, interpret, and generate human language.
Computer Vision: Computer vision allows machines to interpret and process visual information from the world.
Data Science: Data science combines statistics, computing, and domain knowledge to extract insights from data.
Big Data: Big data refers to large and complex datasets that require advanced methods to process.
Data Mining: Data mining discovers patterns and relationships in large datasets.
Feature Engineering: Feature engineering creates new input features to improve model performance.
Overfitting: Overfitting occurs when a model learns noise in the training data, reducing generalization.
Underfitting: Underfitting occurs when a model is too simple to capture underlying patterns in the data.
Cross Validation: Cross-validation evaluates model performance on multiple subsets of the data.
Gradient Descent: Gradient descent is an optimization algorithm used to minimize the error of a model.
Activation Function: An activation function defines the output of a neural network node given an input.
Sigmoid: Sigmoid is an activation function that outputs a value between 0 and 1.
ReLU: ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit) outputs the input directly if positive, otherwise zero.
Softmax: Softmax converts a vector of numbers into probabilities that sum to 1.
Loss Function: A loss function measures how well a model's predictions match the actual data.
Accuracy: Accuracy is the ratio of correct predictions to total predictions made.
Precision: Precision measures the proportion of true positive predictions among all positive predictions.
Recall: Recall measures the proportion of true positive predictions among all actual positives.
F1 Score: F1 Score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall.
Confusion Matrix: A confusion matrix shows the performance of a classification model in terms of true/false positives/negatives.
Regression: Regression predicts a continuous output based on input features.
Linear Regression: Linear regression models the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables.
Logistic Regression: Logistic regression predicts the probability of a binary outcome.
Clustering: Clustering groups similar data points together based on features.
K-Means: K-Means is a popular clustering algorithm that partitions data into k clusters.
Hierarchical Clustering: Hierarchical clustering creates nested clusters organized as a tree.
Dimensionality Reduction: Dimensionality reduction reduces the number of input variables while retaining important information.
PCA: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a technique for dimensionality reduction.
t-SNE: t-SNE is used for visualizing high-dimensional data in two or three dimensions.
Decision Tree: A decision tree splits data into branches based on feature values to make predictions.
Random Forest: Random Forest is an ensemble of decision trees used to improve prediction accuracy.
Support Vector Machine: SVM is a supervised model that finds the optimal hyperplane separating classes.
K-Nearest Neighbors: KNN predicts the class of a data point based on the classes of its neighbors.
Bagging: Bagging combines multiple models to reduce variance and improve stability.
Boosting: Boosting sequentially trains models to correct errors of previous models.
AdaBoost: AdaBoost is a boosting technique that combines weak classifiers into a strong one.
Gradient Boosting: Gradient Boosting builds models in a stage-wise fashion to minimize loss.
XGBoost: XGBoost is an optimized implementation of gradient boosting for high performance.
LightGBM: LightGBM is a fast, distributed gradient boosting framework.
CatBoost: CatBoost is a gradient boosting library that handles categorical features efficiently.
Overfitting Prevention: Techniques like regularization, dropout, and cross-validation prevent overfitting.
Regularization: Regularization adds a penalty to the loss function to reduce model complexity.
L1 Regularization: L1 regularization (Lasso) promotes sparsity in model parameters.
L2 Regularization: L2 regularization (Ridge) reduces the magnitude of model parameters.
Dropout: Dropout randomly ignores some neurons during training to prevent overfitting.
Epoch: An epoch is one complete pass of the training dataset through the model.
Batch Size: Batch size defines how many samples are used in one iteration of model training.
Learning Rate: Learning rate controls how much the model adjusts in response to the error.
Optimization: Optimization finds model parameters that minimize the loss function.
Backpropagation: Backpropagation is the algorithm used to update neural network weights based on error gradients.
Hyperparameter: Hyperparameters are configuration variables external to the model, like learning rate and number of layers.
Grid Search: Grid search tests combinations of hyperparameters to find the optimal configuration.
Random Search: Random search selects random hyperparameter combinations for optimization.
Bayesian Optimization: Bayesian optimization uses probabilistic models to efficiently search hyperparameters.
Transfer Learning: Transfer learning uses knowledge from one task to improve performance on a related task.
Fine Tuning: Fine tuning adapts a pretrained model to a new dataset.
Pretrained Model: A pretrained model is trained on large datasets and used as a starting point for new tasks.
GPT: GPT (Generative Pretrained Transformer) is a language model that generates human-like text.
BERT: BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) is used for NLP tasks like text classification.
Transformer: Transformer is a deep learning architecture that processes sequential data efficiently.
Attention Mechanism: Attention allows a model to focus on important parts of input data.
Self-Attention: Self-attention computes relationships between all elements in a sequence.
Tokenization: Tokenization splits text into smaller units like words or subwords.
Embedding: Embedding maps discrete items like words into continuous vector space.
Word2Vec: Word2Vec converts words into vector representations capturing semantic meaning.
GloVe: GloVe generates word embeddings based on global co-occurrence statistics.
Sentence Embedding: Sentence embeddings represent entire sentences as vectors for NLP tasks.
Text Classification: Text classification assigns labels to text based on its content.
Named Entity Recognition: NER identifies and classifies entities in text like names and locations.
Part-of-Speech Tagging: POS tagging labels words with their grammatical category.
Sentiment Analysis: Sentiment analysis determines the emotional tone of a text.
Machine Translation: Machine translation automatically converts text from one language to another.
Chatbot: A chatbot interacts with humans using natural language.
Speech Recognition: Speech recognition converts spoken language into text.
Text-to-Speech: Text-to-speech converts written text into spoken words.
Voice Assistant: Voice assistants respond to spoken commands and perform tasks.
AI Ethics: AI ethics addresses moral considerations in designing and using AI systems.
Responsible AI: Responsible AI ensures AI systems are safe, fair, and transparent.
Explainable AI: Explainable AI makes machine decisions understandable to humans.

Algorithm: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or performing a task.
Heuristic: A rule-of-thumb approach to problem-solving that is not guaranteed to be optimal.
Data Structure: A way to organize and store data for efficient access and modification.
Array: An ordered collection of elements accessible by index.
Linked List: A data structure where elements are nodes connected by pointers.
Stack: A data structure following LIFO (Last In First Out) principle.
Queue: A data structure following FIFO (First In First Out) principle.
Tree: A hierarchical data structure with a root node and child nodes.
Binary Tree: A tree where each node has at most two children.
Binary Search Tree: A binary tree where left children are smaller and right children are larger than the parent node.
Graph: A set of nodes connected by edges representing relationships.
Directed Graph: A graph where edges have a direction from one node to another.
Undirected Graph: A graph where edges have no direction, representing bidirectional relationships.
Weighted Graph: A graph where edges have associated weights representing cost, distance, or capacity.
Adjacency Matrix: A matrix representing graph connections where each element indicates an edge.
Adjacency List: A list representation where each node stores a list of its neighbors.
Hash Table: A data structure that maps keys to values using a hash function.
Hash Function: A function that converts input data into a fixed-size integer for indexing in hash tables.
Collision: When two inputs produce the same hash value in a hash table.
Linked Hash Table: A hash table using linked lists to handle collisions.
Heap: A complete binary tree used for efficiently finding the maximum or minimum element.
Priority Queue: A queue where each element has a priority, and the highest-priority element is dequeued first.
Graph Traversal: Methods for visiting nodes in a graph, like BFS or DFS.
BFS: Breadth-First Search explores all neighbors at the current depth before moving deeper.
DFS: Depth-First Search explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking.
Recursion: A function that calls itself directly or indirectly to solve a problem.
Iteration: Repeatedly executing a block of code using loops.
Sorting Algorithm: An algorithm that arranges elements in a particular order.
Bubble Sort: A simple sorting algorithm that repeatedly swaps adjacent elements if out of order.
Selection Sort: A sorting algorithm that repeatedly selects the minimum element and places it at the beginning.
Insertion Sort: A sorting algorithm that builds the final sorted array one element at a time.
Merge Sort: A divide-and-conquer sorting algorithm that divides, sorts, and merges arrays.
Quick Sort: A divide-and-conquer sorting algorithm that partitions arrays around a pivot.
Heap Sort: A sorting algorithm that converts the array into a heap and repeatedly extracts the max element.
Search Algorithm: An algorithm used to find elements or information in a data structure.
Linear Search: A search method that checks each element in sequence.
Binary Search: A search method that repeatedly divides a sorted array to find the target.
Time Complexity: A measure of the number of operations an algorithm performs relative to input size.
Space Complexity: A measure of the amount of memory an algorithm uses relative to input size.
Big O Notation: A notation describing the worst-case time or space complexity of an algorithm.
Big Theta Notation: A notation describing the exact asymptotic behavior of an algorithm.
Big Omega Notation: A notation describing the lower bound of an algorithm's complexity.
Computer Architecture: The design and organization of a computer's components and systems.
CPU: The central processing unit executes instructions and performs calculations.
GPU: The graphics processing unit accelerates rendering and parallel computations.
RAM: Random access memory stores data temporarily for quick access.
ROM: Read-only memory stores permanent data and instructions.
Cache: High-speed memory used to reduce latency and speed up access to frequently used data.
Registers: Small, fast storage locations inside the CPU for immediate data access.
Bus: A communication system that transfers data between components inside a computer.
Instruction Set: A set of commands a CPU can execute.
Firmware: Software programmed into hardware to provide low-level control.
Operating System: Software that manages hardware resources and provides services for applications.
Process: An instance of a program in execution.
Thread: The smallest unit of execution within a process.
Multithreading: Running multiple threads concurrently to improve performance.
Parallel Computing: Performing multiple computations simultaneously across multiple processors.
Distributed Computing: Using multiple computers to solve a problem collaboratively.
Networking: Connecting computers to share data and resources.
IP Address: A unique identifier for a device on a network.
TCP/IP: A set of protocols for communication over the Internet.
HTTP: HyperText Transfer Protocol used for web communication.
HTTPS: HTTP secured with encryption via SSL/TLS.
Socket: An endpoint for sending or receiving data over a network.
DNS: Domain Name System translates domain names into IP addresses.
Cloud Computing: Delivering computing resources and services over the Internet.
SaaS: Software as a Service allows users to access applications hosted online.
PaaS: Platform as a Service provides tools for developers to build applications.
IaaS: Infrastructure as a Service provides virtualized computing resources.
Virtual Machine: An emulation of a computer system running on physical hardware.
Container: A lightweight, portable environment for running applications consistently.
Docker: A platform for containerizing applications and managing deployments.
Kubernetes: An orchestration system for managing containerized applications at scale.
Blockchain: A distributed ledger technology for recording transactions securely.
Cryptocurrency: Digital currency secured using cryptography and blockchain technology.
Bitcoin: The first and most widely recognized cryptocurrency.
Ethereum: A blockchain platform that supports smart contracts and decentralized applications.
Smart Contract: A self-executing contract with terms directly written in code.
NFT: Non-fungible token representing ownership of a unique digital asset.
Cybersecurity: The practice of protecting systems, networks, and data from digital attacks.
Encryption: Converting data into a coded form to prevent unauthorized access.
Decryption: Converting encrypted data back into its original form.
Symmetric Encryption: Encryption where the same key is used for both encryption and decryption.
Asymmetric Encryption: Encryption using a public key for encryption and a private key for decryption.
Firewall: A system that controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on rules.
Antivirus: Software that detects, prevents, and removes malicious software.

Machine Learning: A subset of AI where systems learn patterns from data without explicit programming.
Supervised Learning: Machine learning using labeled datasets to train models.
Unsupervised Learning: Machine learning using unlabeled datasets to discover patterns.
Reinforcement Learning: Machine learning where an agent learns by interacting with an environment and receiving rewards.
Neural Network: A network of interconnected nodes inspired by the human brain for pattern recognition.
Deep Learning: A type of neural network with multiple layers that can model complex patterns.
Convolutional Neural Network: A neural network specialized in processing grid-like data, like images.
Recurrent Neural Network: A neural network suitable for sequential data like text and time series.
Activation Function: A function that determines the output of a neural network node.
Sigmoid Function: An activation function that outputs a value between 0 and 1.
ReLU: Rectified Linear Unit, a popular activation function for hidden layers in neural networks.
Softmax: An activation function that converts outputs into probability distributions.
Loss Function: A function that measures the difference between predicted and actual values.
Gradient Descent: An optimization algorithm used to minimize the loss function in training.
Backpropagation: The process of updating neural network weights by propagating errors backward.
Overfitting: When a model learns the training data too well and performs poorly on new data.
Underfitting: When a model is too simple to capture the underlying patterns in data.
Regularization: Techniques to prevent overfitting, such as L1 or L2 penalties.
Dropout: A regularization technique where random nodes are ignored during training.
Batch Normalization: A method to improve training speed and stability by normalizing layer inputs.
Learning Rate: A hyperparameter that controls how much weights are updated during training.
Epoch: One complete pass through the entire training dataset.
Batch Size: The number of training examples used in one iteration.
Data Preprocessing: Preparing raw data for training, including cleaning and normalization.
Feature Engineering: Creating meaningful features from raw data to improve model performance.
Dimensionality Reduction: Reducing the number of features while preserving important information.
Principal Component Analysis: A technique for dimensionality reduction using linear combinations.
K-Means: A popular clustering algorithm that partitions data into K clusters.
Hierarchical Clustering: A clustering method that builds a hierarchy of clusters.
Anomaly Detection: Identifying rare or unusual data points.
Recommendation System: A system that suggests items to users based on their preferences or behavior.
Collaborative Filtering: Recommendation based on the preferences of similar users.
Content-Based Filtering: Recommendation based on item features and user preferences.
Natural Language Processing: A field of AI focused on understanding and generating human language.
Tokenization: Breaking text into words or subwords for analysis.
Stemming: Reducing words to their root form.
Lemmatization: Reducing words to their dictionary form.
Bag of Words: A method of representing text as a collection of word counts.
TF-IDF: Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency, a text representation method.
Word Embedding: Mapping words to vectors that capture semantic meaning.
Sequence-to-Sequence: A model that maps input sequences to output sequences, used in translation.
Attention Mechanism: A method for focusing on important parts of input data in neural networks.
Transformer: A neural network architecture based on attention mechanisms.
BERT: Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers, a pretrained language model.
GPT: Generative Pretrained Transformer, a language model that generates text.
Chatbot: A program that simulates human conversation using AI or rules.
Turing Test: A test of a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior indistinguishable from a human.
AI Ethics: Principles for responsible design and use of AI.
Bias in AI: Systematic errors in AI outputs due to biased data or models.
Explainable AI: Techniques to make AI decisions understandable to humans.
Computer Vision: A field of AI that enables machines to interpret visual data.
Object Detection: Identifying objects in images or video frames.
Image Classification: Assigning a label to an entire image.
Semantic Segmentation: Classifying each pixel in an image.
Optical Character Recognition: Converting printed or handwritten text into machine-readable form.
Augmented Reality: Overlaying virtual content on the real world.
Virtual Reality: Immersing users in a fully simulated environment.
Robotics: Design and use of robots to perform tasks.
Sensor: A device that detects physical properties and converts them to signals.
Actuator: A component that moves or controls a mechanism in response to a signal.
Embedded System: A computer system designed for a specific function within a device.
Internet of Things: Network of interconnected devices that communicate and exchange data.
